A Party who plays a musical Instrument while another Person is singing (or playing another instrument).
A Party who performs spoken word or mime.
An Engineer that has worked on a smaller percentage of a project tham the main Engineer.
A SoundEngineer responsible for contributing additional mixes to a recording.
A Performer that is not a LeadPerformer.
An ProgrammingEngineer that has worked on a smaller percentage of a project than the main ProgrammingEngineer.
A StudioProducer who makes a minor additional contribution to a recording.
A Party acting as the central moderator of a program.
A Party who trains and looks after animals.
A Party who creates an animated work.
A Party who makes annotations on a manuscript.
A Party reading news or describing events.
A Party handling the administrative elements of the A&R department and maintaining the budgets for artists signed to a label by working with accounting and legal personnel.
A Party responsible for searching new Artists for a record label (artist and repertoire coordinator).
A Party responsible for the supply and safety of weapons in a production.
A Creator of a copy of a piece of art.
A Director who oversees the Artists and craftspeople who build the sets.

A principal Contributor to a Performance of a MusicalWork or a NonMusicalWork that results in the creation of a Resource, or a principal creative Contributor to a Resource that is not a result of a Performance. Note: Used for naming groups as well as individuals.
An Engineer responsible for the recording of Artist Background Vocals.

An Engineer responsible for the process of recording vocals on a project and dealing with technical issues and decisions. He or she operates the recording equipment (or supervises the operation of the recording equipment) during vocal Performances and makes aesthetic choices in order to obtain the sound and concepts the artist and producer are looking for.
A Party who is the second head of the LightingTechnicians.
An assistant of a Conductor. An AssistantConductor is not a subordinate to the Conductor, but rather a collaborator or at least on a somewhat equal level.
An assistant of an Editor (aka editorial assistant). This role is both an editorial and an administrative role.

An Engineer responsible for assisting another Engineer(s). They often keep all logs of Sessions and materials and operate equipment. They should also have enough engineering skills that they can step in for an Engineer in case of an absence.
A Party who is delegated some area of responsibility on a project, but reports to the Producer or CoProducer(s) (aka additional producer).
An Artist commonly associated with a Work as one of its Performers, and whose identity is only used for accurate Work identification.
A Party who trains Performers in the development of aural skills.
A Party who sings in the background.

A Party primary or actively responsible for the process of recording and/or mixing a project as well as technical issues and decisions. The Engineer operates (or oversees the operation of) the equipment during the recording process and makes creative and aesthetic choices in collaboration with the Artist and producer in order to realize the sounds and concepts envisioned for the project. In the classical world, this is often referred to as a balance engineer.
The principal member of a MusicGroup.
A Party who binds an item.
A Designer of a book binding.
A Designer of a book (including arrangement of type and illustration, choice of materials, etc.).
A Designer of a dust jacket for a book.
A Designer of a bookplate (an identification label commonly on the inside front cover of books).
A Party providing general support in the production of a radio programme.
A Party working as a Journalist for a broadcast programme.
A Creator of artistic handwriting or lettering.
A Party who carries out woodwork.
A Creator of a map or other cartographic work.
A Party selecting talent (Actors, singers, Dancers, etc.).
A Party who gives an informal lecture, typically on radio.
An Editor who examines Creations and removes objectionable content.
A Party who is the head of the LightingTechnicians.
A group of Parties who perform vocally together. Typically, Choirs consist of at least 2 people in an combination of different vocal ranges.
A Conductor who directs Vocalists in a Choir.
An Artist with skills that are typical for circus performances.
A Party who operates the clapboard at the beginning of a shot.
A Party who announces and plays recorded music in a music club.
A Director who is sharing some or all of a director's responsabilities with a Director or another CoDirector.
An ExecutiveProducer who is not the only ExecutiveProducer.
A Party responsible for separating the original artwork into individual color components for printing.
An Artist who makes people laugh (by telling funny stories or by acting).
One of a group of Artists who creates an original master album or single mix.
A Party who is sharing some or all of a mixing engineer's responsabilities with a MixingEngineer or another CoMixer.
A Party who provides interpretation, analysis, or a discussion of a subject matter.
A Party commissioning material for a broadcast programme.
A producer responsible for supervising and/or exercising control over the work assigned to other Producers, Engineers, and others on the project.
A Creator of a computer program.
The leader of the first violin section in an Orchestra.
A Party who leads or conducts a Performance by a group of Musicians.
A Party giving professional advice on matters of production technique or on content who does not appear in the programme.
A Party who checks the continuity of a series of camera shots.
A Party who is hired to perform work.
A producer who is sharing some or all of a producer's responsabilities with a Producer or another CoProducer.
A Party who is the writer of a letter or other communication.
A Party who performs a dance.
A Creator of technical drawings derived from designs made by other people.
A Party who helps train an Actor in diction and/or the use of dialects.
A Party responsible for assembling, synchronizing, and editing all the dialogues in a film or television production.

An Engineer is responsible for the operation of a Digital Audio Workstation (DAW) during recording and mix sessions including the archiving and maintenance of the recorded material (basically data files). The DigitalAudioWorkstationEngineer is not generally called upon to make major aesthetic judgments.
An Engineer responsible for operating equipment for editing (in today’s world generally a digital audio workstation). They can, from time to time, be called on to make aesthetic choices.
A Party who leads or supervises actors, e.g. in the prodution of a movie.
A Party responsible for the functioning and maintenance of digital recordings using Direct Stream Digital format equipment.
An Organization responsible for delivering material provided by a ProductionCompany.
A Party who announces and plays recorded music.
A Creator of a plan for constructing something.
A Party who helps an Actor to put on and take off a costume.
A Creator who adds the dubbing into a Resource.
A Party responsible for the preparation of a publication.
A Party responsible for the preparation of a news broadcast of the day.
A Creator processing and encoding a Resource for distribution.
A Party that is responsible for technical aspects. This includes RecordingEngineer, but may also cover roles in other content production processes.
A group of two or more Parties performing a MusicalWork together. Note: An Ensemble may be of any size or any grouping of Performers from a vocal duo to a full orchestra.

A Party who secures funding for a project. He or she may be responsible for the overall concept. He or she may monitor the project from time to time to ensure that the producer and Artist are on track.
A Party who contributes his expertise to a programme.
A Director responsible for the choreography of fight scenes.
A Party who edits an audio-visual production for publishing.
A Party (individual or company) that is responsible for the financing of an audio-visual production.
A Party that is responsible for (part of) the soundtrack used in an audio-visual Resource.
A Party acting on the studio floor on behalf of the Director.
A CameraOperator who adjusts the focus of the camera.
A Party who creates incidental sound effects in post-production.
A Party who edits sound effects created by a FoleyArtist.
A SoundMixer who works with a FoleyArtist to create sound effects.
A Party drawing pictures or picture elements as content for programmes.
A Party procuring and maintaining vegetation on a set.
A Party supporting CameraOperators and LightingTechnicians with specialized equipment (e.g. camera cranes).
A Conductor who is working with an Orchestra on a temporary basis.
A Person that is a member of a MusicGroup.
A Party who prepares the hair of an Actor.

A Party that initiates the creation of a SoundRecording or Resource and is sometimes referred to as a commissioning rights holder. An InitialProducer may be a Person or an Organization and the term contrasts with the role of a StudioProducer.
A Party who interviews, i.e. talks to somebody for the purpose of eliciting his opinions.
A central or primary Character in a storyline.
A Party who is the head of the Grips.
A Party performing as a leading character.
A Party who is responsible for the crew in charge of the set decoration.
A Performer that plays the role of the protagonist in a film or play.
A Party who is a lead Vocalist.
A Party responsible for the lighting.
A Party managing all aspects relating to filming in specific places.
A Party who prepares the make up of an Actor.
A Party responsible for manufacturing a device or a piece of technical equipment.

An Engineer who is the last creative bridge between the mix process and the distribution process. He or she generally works with a final mix of a project and makes final adjustments to the sound before distribution while maintaining the vision of the artist, producer and label.
An assistant of a MasteringEngineer (aka assistant mastering engineer).
A Party who creates artworks used in making scenery and locations that do not exist.
An Artist who creates an original master album or single mix.
An Engineer combining different audio recording elements into a final version.
An assistant of a MixingEngineer (aka assistant mixing engineer).
An Arranger who adds the final touches or subtle nuances to the musical arrangement of a recording.
A Creator of a copy of a Composer or Arranger's manuscript.
A Director responsible for music in the production of a film or a radio program.
A group of individuals who perform vocally and/or instrumentally together.
A Party who performs a MusicalWork either vocally or instrumentally.
A Party who tells a story or gives an account of an event.
A producer of a news program.
A Party who reads news stories.
A Type used when a sender of a DdexMessage wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is known, but not specified.
A large group of Parties performing a MusicalWork together, predominantly using musical instruments rather than voice. An Orchestra is typically led by a Conductor.
An Artist who is an original Artist.
An Engineer combining different audio recordings into an overdub.
A Director responsible for photography (aka director of photgraphy or cinematographer).
A Party who sings songs to be mimed in films by Actors.
A producer responsible for post-production processes.
A producer responsible for pre-production processes.
An Engineer involved in pre-production processes.
A Party who performs a MusicalWork either vocally or instrumentally and would be considered the principal Contributor for the piece.
A Party that provides only administrative support for a Producer.
An Organization responsible for a production (also called a production house).
A Party who coordinates the activities around preparing a physical or digital Release.
A department of a ProductionCompany responsible for a production.
A Person who coordinates a production.
A Party providing secretarial support in a production.
An Engineer involved in a recording Project.
A Party using electronic devices, such as sequencers, to generate sounds of musical Instruments in a music production.
A Party responsible for the functioning and maintenance of digital recorders and digital audio workstations.
A producer of a program, e.g. a TV or radio program.
A Party responsible for purchasing, acquiring and/or manufacturing anything needed for a production.
A Party responsible for the coherence and continuity of a publication.
A Party who operates puppets in a Performance.
A Party operating equipment to produce fire and explosions.
A Party supervising the technical aspects of a sound or video recording Session.
An assistant of a RecordingEngineer (aka assistant recording engineer).
An Editor who prepares text for publication.
A producer of a reissue of a SoundRecording.
An Artist whose work has been remixed.
An Artist who creates a finished product that is different from the original master album or single mix, e.g. a Dance Remix, Radio Remix, Rock Remix.
A MixingEngineer who creates a finished product that is different from the original master album or single mix, e.g. a Dance Remix, Radio Remix, Rock Remix.
A Party who coaches ballet Dancers or opera singers.
A Party responsible for researching a project (e.g. gathering ideas, background information etc.).
The head of a team of Researchers.
A member of a team of Researchers.
A Party responsible for restaging a Work (with minimal contribution to the content).
A Grip operating equipment to satisfy rigging needs on a set.
A RightsController as it appears on a Product.
A Party who is a junior member of the production team doing all kinds of supporting jobs.
A Party in charge of a studio set.
A Party who tracks the progress of a production based on a script.
A Director in charge of the second unit in a film production.
A Party (individual or company) that is responsible for the production of a series.
A Designer, also known as a stage designer, who is in charge of designing and creating the sets that appear in films, on television programmes as well as in the theatre.
A Party in charge of decorating a set in a production.
A Party translating spoken words into sign language.
A Party who performs the featured Part of a MusicalWork (or a section of it) alone or with only supporting accompaniment.
A Party responsible for sound production.
A Party operating audio equipment to capture sound.
A Party operating audio equipment to record sound.
A Party oversees the work of all sound personnel on multi-camera productions. During live programmes they are responsible for mixing sound sources for immediate transmission.
A Party who performs using his voice without singing.
A Party giving financial support for an Event or a Creation.
An Party, also called the monitor engineer, who is responsible for the operation of the monitor mixing console, maintenance and repair of a band's in-ears, onstage, and backline gear.
A Performer relaying a story with dramatic or theatrical interpretation.

An Engineer responsible for the process of recording an Orchestra on a project and dealing with technical issues and decisions. The StringEngineer operates the recording equipment (or oversees the operation of the recording equipment) during orchestral Performances and makes aesthetic choices in order to get the sound and concepts the artist and producer are looking for.
A StudioProducer working with the individual instruments/elements of the recording and not the overall production.
A director in charge of the performance of the strings section of an Orchestra.
A Party working as a Conductor in a studio.
A Party who performs a MusicalWork either vocally or instrumentally in a studio.
A Party who is employed in a studio and contributes to the making of a Resource.

A Party who directs, and has overall creative and technical oversight of, the entire recording project and the individual recording sessions that are a part of the project. The StudioProducer participates in and/or supervises the recording session and works directly with the Artist, Musicians and Engineers. The StudioProducer makes creative, technical and aesthetic decisions that realize the goals of both the Artist and the SoundRecording CopyrightHolder in the creation of musical content. The producer may perform, direct Performances, choose final takes or versions, and oversees the selection of songs, Musicians, singers, Arrangers, studios, etc. The StudioProducer in collaboration with the artist, assigns credits to Performers and technical personnel, and is responsible for supplying accurate crediting information to the record label or media company as official documentation. Other duties of the StudioProducer may include, but are not limited to, overseeing other staffing needs, keeping budgets and schedules, adhering to deadlines, supervising mastering and overall quality control. Note: a ddexStudio:Producer is a Person and thus may contrast with the role of an InitialProducer.
A Party that is responsible for the creation of SubTitles/captions.
An Actor playing a secondary role.
An assistant of a MixingEngineer responsible for SurroundSound.
A Party in charge of cueing and preparing video inserts into a program.
A Party responsible for technical aspects of a production.
An Engineer who is a graduate of an official Tonmeister program that includes score reading and electronics training as well education in recording, mixing and editing techniques.
A Party supervising the technical aspects of a tracking Session.
A Party supervising the technical aspects of a transfers and safeties Session.
A Party responsible for managing drivers and co-ordinating the transportation in a production.
A Party writing summaries of various aspects of a production.
A Type of an Entity used when a sender of a DdexMessage wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is unknown.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.
A Party in charge of a video production.
A Party responsible for a music video production. The VideoMusicalDirector conceives artistic and dramatic aspects while instructing the musical act, technical crew, actors, models, and dancers.
A Party (individual or company) that is responsible for the financing of a Video.
A Party operating video equipment to mix video feeds.
An Editor who prepares video or film footage.
An Arranger who adds the final touches or subtle nuances to the vocal arrangement of a recording.
An Engineer responsible for editing the vocal elements of a recording.
An assistant of an Engineer responsible for editing the vocal elements of a recording.
An Engineer responsible for the capture of the vocal elements of a recording.

A producer with overall creative and technical control of the vocal recording on a project and the individual recording Sessions that are a part of that project. He or she is present in the recording studio or at the location recording and works directly with the vocalist(s) and engineer. The VocalProducer makes creative and aesthetic decisions that realize the goals of both the artist and the label goals in the creation of the vocals.
A Party who performs using his voice.
A Party responsible for managing clothes and/or costumes.
A ResourceGroupType indicating that a Release is made up of several volumes or carriers, e.g. of two CDs.
A ResourceGroupType indicating that a Release (e.g. a boxed set) comprises several other Releases. This value applies to the ResourceGroup containing the ReleaseComponents.
A ResourceGroupType indicating that a Release is made up of a compound Work. This is often used to separate classical movements.
A ResourceGroupType indicating that a Release (e.g. a boxed set) comprises several other Releases. This value applies to the ResourceGroup contained in the ComponentRelease.
A ResourceGroupType indicating that a Release is made up of several Sides. This may only be used when communicating data for physical products.
A Type of relationship between two Resources.
A ResourceRelationshipType of a Resource that is closely related to another Resource because some content (e.g. a song) has been taken from it.
A ResourceRelationshipType of a Resource that is contained in the primary Resource.
: Image, MIDI, SheetMusic, Software, SoundRecording, Text, UserDefinedResource, Video
A still visual Recording or illustration of an object. Examples: a Photograph or a GraphicImage.
A Set of computer instructions which enables a sound processor to generate sounds (using the Musical Instrument Digital Interface as defined by the MIDI Manufacturers Association (MMA)).
A hand-written or printed form of musical notation.
A program that enables a Computer to perform a specific task(s).
A written Manifestation. Examples: the Lyrics of a MusicalWork or the text of an interview.
A hand-written or printed form of musical notation.
A Type of relationship between a Resource and a Work.
A Resource based on multiple Works where one of them is played by new musicians.
The Resource is the recording of a Medley.
A Resource based on multiple Works (or on a CompositeMusicalWork).
The Resource is the recording of a MusicalWorkWithSamples.
A Resource based on a single Work.
A Type of Revenue earned by the SoundRecording, according to the way the Revenue is generated.
A Type of relationship between two RightShares.
A RightShare which entitles a Party to issue Licenses for a Work.

A RightShare of a MusicalWork as agreed between the writers. The sum of all MusicalWorkManuscriptShares on a MusicalWork equals 100%. It is possible (though unusual) for MusicalWorkManuscriptShares to vary by Territory or Rights Type. Manuscript Shares are often referred to as Writer Shares.
A RightShare as calculated for the collection of money for RightShares.

A RightShare owned by the OriginalPublisher (i.e. the MusicPublisher who has been given the rights by the writer, as opposed to by another Publisher) of the MusicalWork. They are also referred to as Stakeholder Shares or Primary Publishers Shares.
A Type of rights claim policy.
A Policy where the recipient of the message shall block any use of a Release or Resource that meets the condition.
A Policy where the recipient of the message shall report any use of a Release or Resource that meets the condition to the relevant rights holder(s).
A Policy where the recipient of the message may make the Release or Resource that meets the condition available for commercial purposes and shall report revenues to the relevant rights holder(s).
A State in which there is a Conflict.
A State in which there is no Conflict.
A State in which a RightsClaim is pending review.

A RecordCompany responsible for administering Rights in a Resource or Release. Note: This role does not entail any ownership or control of the exploitation of Rights, although the same Party may also be an owner or controller of Rights in that way.
A Party administrating Rights on behalf of one or more RightsControllers.
A Party who owns and/or controls Rights in a MusicalWork and/or a Resource.
A Party that collects and distributes royalties on behalf of one or more RightsControllers.
A Type of an Entity used when a sender of a DdexMessage wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is unknown.
A RightsController who owns and/or controls the original Rights in a MusicalWork and/or a Resource.
A RightsController who is a successor in title.
A Type of Right which is covered.
: MakeAvailableRight, MechanicalRight, PerformingRight, PrintRight, ReproductionRight, SynchronizationRight, UserDefined
The Right to make a Work available to the public.
The Right to record and distribute a Work on a Carrier.
The Right to perform a Work. This is, to present a Work by action such as playing, reciting, singing, or projecting to the public in their presence.
The Right to make a visual copy of a Work (and distribute it).
The Right to make a physical reproduction of a Work.
The Right to include and combine a Work either completely or in parts in timed relation with Works of other types for the making of an audio-visual or multimedia Creation or a database.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.
A Type of Right which is covered.
The Right to record and distribute a Work on a Carrier.
The Right to perform a Work. This is, to present a Work by action such as playing, reciting, singing, or projecting to the public in their presence.
The Right to make a visual copy of a Work (and distribute it).
The Right to include and combine a Work either completely or in parts in timed relation with Works of other types for the making of an audio-visual or multimedia Creation or a database.
A Type of RoyaltyRate according to the calculation method, as used in the MWNL messages.
: ControlledCompositionRoyaltyRate, MinimumStatutoryRoyaltyRate, NegotiatedRoyaltyRate, ReducedStatutoryRoyaltyRate, StatutoryRoyaltyRate, PPD, RetailPrice
A RoyaltyRate calculated through provisions of a contract containing a 'controlled composition' clause.
A RoyaltyRate negotiated between individual Licensor and Licensee.
A Published Price to Dealer (PPD) or wholesale unit price used as the basis for calculating a royalty rate.
A Price at which a Product is offered to Consumers.
A RoyaltyRate in absolute monetary terms.
A percentage or value Rate at which royalties are due, representing the percentage of some Amount (e.g., RetailPrice) payable in royalties.

A Session focusing on Vocal Performances.

A Party who binds an item.
A Designer of a book binding.
A Designer of a book (including arrangement of type and illustration, choice of materials, etc.).
A Designer of a dust jacket for a book.
A Designer of a bookplate (an identification label commonly on the inside front cover of books).
A Party providing general support in the production of a radio programme.
A Party working as a Journalist for a broadcast programme.
A Party who carries out woodwork.
A Party selecting talent (Actors, singers, Dancers, etc.).
An Editor who examines Creations and removes objectionable content.
A Party who is the head of the LightingTechnicians.
A Party who operates the clapboard at the beginning of a shot.
An ExecutiveProducer who is not the only ExecutiveProducer.
A Party commissioning material for a broadcast programme.
A producer responsible for supervising and/or exercising control over the work assigned to other Producers, Engineers, and others on the project.
A Party giving professional advice on matters of production technique or on content who does not appear in the programme.
A Party who checks the continuity of a series of camera shots.
A Party who is hired to perform work.
A producer who is sharing some or all of a producer's responsabilities with a Producer or another CoProducer.
A Party who is the writer of a letter or other communication.
A Party who helps train an Actor in diction and/or the use of dialects.

An Engineer is responsible for the operation of a Digital Audio Workstation (DAW) during recording and mix sessions including the archiving and maintenance of the recorded material (basically data files). The DigitalAudioWorkstationEngineer is not generally called upon to make major aesthetic judgments.
An Engineer responsible for operating equipment for editing (in today’s world generally a digital audio workstation). They can, from time to time, be called on to make aesthetic choices.
A Party who leads or supervises actors, e.g. in the prodution of a movie.
A Party responsible for the functioning and maintenance of digital recordings using Direct Stream Digital format equipment.
An Organization responsible for delivering material provided by a ProductionCompany.
A Party who helps an Actor to put on and take off a costume.
A Creator who adds the dubbing into a Resource.
A Party responsible for the preparation of a publication.
A Party responsible for the preparation of a news broadcast of the day.
A Creator processing and encoding a Resource for distribution.
A Party that is responsible for technical aspects. This includes RecordingEngineer, but may also cover roles in other content production processes.

A Party who secures funding for a project. He or she may be responsible for the overall concept. He or she may monitor the project from time to time to ensure that the producer and Artist are on track.
A Party who contributes his expertise to a programme.
A Director responsible for the choreography of fight scenes.
A Party who edits an audio-visual production for publishing.
A Party (individual or company) that is responsible for the financing of an audio-visual production.
A Party that is responsible for (part of) the soundtrack used in an audio-visual Resource.
A Party acting on the studio floor on behalf of the Director.
A CameraOperator who adjusts the focus of the camera.
A Party who creates incidental sound effects in post-production.
A Party who edits sound effects created by a FoleyArtist.
A SoundMixer who works with a FoleyArtist to create sound effects.
A Party drawing pictures or picture elements as content for programmes.
A Party procuring and maintaining vegetation on a set.
A Party supporting CameraOperators and LightingTechnicians with specialized equipment (e.g. camera cranes).
A Party who prepares the hair of an Actor.

A Party that initiates the creation of a SoundRecording or Resource and is sometimes referred to as a commissioning rights holder. An InitialProducer may be a Person or an Organization and the term contrasts with the role of a StudioProducer.
A Party who is the head of the Grips.
A Party who is responsible for the crew in charge of the set decoration.
A Party responsible for the lighting.
A Party managing all aspects relating to filming in specific places.
A Party who prepares the make up of an Actor.
A Party responsible for manufacturing a device or a piece of technical equipment.

An Engineer who is the last creative bridge between the mix process and the distribution process. He or she generally works with a final mix of a project and makes final adjustments to the sound before distribution while maintaining the vision of the artist, producer and label.
An assistant of a MasteringEngineer (aka assistant mastering engineer).
A Party who creates artworks used in making scenery and locations that do not exist.
An Engineer combining different audio recording elements into a final version.
An assistant of a MixingEngineer (aka assistant mixing engineer).
A Director responsible for music in the production of a film or a radio program.
A Party who performs a MusicalWork either vocally or instrumentally.
A producer of a news program.
An Engineer combining different audio recordings into an overdub.
A Director responsible for photography (aka director of photgraphy or cinematographer).
A producer responsible for post-production processes.
A Party responsible for the functioning and maintenance of digital recorders and digital audio workstations.
A producer responsible for pre-production processes.
An Engineer involved in pre-production processes.
An Organization responsible for a production.
A department of a ProductionCompany responsible for a production.
A Person who coordinates a production.
A Party providing secretarial support in a production.
A producer of a program, e.g. a TV or radio program.
A Party writing summaries of various aspects of a production.
A Party responsible for purchasing, acquiring and/or manufacturing anything needed for a production.
A Party responsible for the coherence and continuity of a publication.
A Party operating equipment to produce fire and explosions.
A Party supervising the technical aspects of a sound or video recording Session.
An assistant of a RecordingEngineer (aka assistant recording engineer).
An Editor who prepares text for publication.
A producer of a reissue of a SoundRecording.
A MixingEngineer who creates a finished product that is different from the original master album or single mix, e.g. a Dance Remix, Radio Remix, Rock Remix.
A Party who coaches ballet Dancers or opera singers.
A Party responsible for researching a project (e.g. gathering ideas, background information etc.).
The head of a team of Researchers.
A member of a team of Researchers.
A Party responsible for restaging a Work (with minimal contribution to the content).
A Grip operating equipment to satisfy rigging needs on a set.
A RightsController as it appears on a Product.
A Party who is a junior member of the production team doing all kinds of supporting jobs.
A Party in charge of a studio set.
A Party who tracks the progress of a production based on a script.
A Director in charge of the second unit in a film production.
A Party (individual or company) that is responsible for the production of a series.
A Designer, also known as a stage designer, who is in charge of designing and creating the sets that appear in films, on television programmes as well as in the theatre.
A Party in charge of decorating a set in a production.
A Party responsible for sound production.
A Party operating audio equipment to capture sound.
A Party operating audio equipment to record sound.
A Party giving financial support for an Event or a Creation.

An Engineer responsible for the process of recording an Orchestra on a project and dealing with technical issues and decisions. The StringEngineer operates the recording equipment (or oversees the operation of the recording equipment) during orchestral Performances and makes aesthetic choices in order to get the sound and concepts the artist and producer are looking for.
A StudioProducer working with the individual instruments/elements of the recording and not the overall production.
A Party working as a Conductor in a studio.
A Party who is employed in a studio and contributes to the making of a Resource.

A Party who directs, and has overall creative and technical oversight of, the entire recording project and the individual recording sessions that are a part of the project. The StudioProducer participates in and/or supervises the recording session and works directly with the Artist, Musicians and Engineers. The StudioProducer makes creative, technical and aesthetic decisions that realize the goals of both the Artist and the SoundRecording CopyrightHolder in the creation of musical content. The producer may perform, direct Performances, choose final takes or versions, and oversees the selection of songs, Musicians, singers, Arrangers, studios, etc. The StudioProducer in collaboration with the artist, assigns credits to Performers and technical personnel, and is responsible for supplying accurate crediting information to the record label or media company as official documentation. Other duties of the StudioProducer may include, but are not limited to, overseeing other staffing needs, keeping budgets and schedules, adhering to deadlines, supervising mastering and overall quality control. Note: a ddexStudio:Producer is a Person and thus may contrast with the role of an InitialProducer.
A Party that is responsible for the creation of SubTitles/captions.
A Party in charge of cueing and preparing video inserts into a program.
A Party responsible for technical aspects of a production.
An Engineer who is a graduate of an official Tonmeister program that includes score reading and electronics training as well education in recording, mixing and editing techniques.
A Party supervising the technical aspects of a tracking Session.
A Party supervising the technical aspects of a transfers and safeties Session.
A Party responsible for managing drivers and co-ordinating the transportation in a production.
A Party in charge of a video production.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.
A Party (individual or company) that is responsible for the financing of a Video.
A Party operating video equipment to mix video feeds.
An Editor who prepares video or film footage.

A producer with overall creative and technical control of the vocal recording on a project and the individual recording Sessions that are a part of that project. He or she is present in the recording studio or at the location recording and works directly with the vocalist(s) and engineer. The VocalProducer makes creative and aesthetic decisions that realize the goals of both the artist and the label goals in the creation of the vocals.
A Party responsible for managing clothes and/or costumes.
A Creator of a copy of a piece of art.
A Creator of artistic handwriting or lettering.
A Creator of a map or other cartographic work.
A Creator of a computer program.
A Creator of technical drawings derived from designs made by other people.
A Creator of a plan for constructing something.
A Creator of a copy of a Composer or Arranger's manuscript.
A Type used when a sender of a DdexMessage wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is known, but not specified.
A Type of an Entity used when a sender of a DdexMessage wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is unknown.

A Party responsible for an artistic input to the production of a Resource (e.g. a SoundRecording or audiovisual recording). This is deprecated as an allowed value for a role code and the code StudioProducer should be used instead.
Deprecation: This allowed value has been deprecated in 2017-11. DDEX advises that this value will be removed at a future date and therefore recommends against using it.
A Type of SubTitle which defines its origin, form or the function.
A SubTitle that provides details about a location associated with a Resource.
A SubTitle that allows differentiating different versions of the same Resource in accordance with the ISRC standard. This value is only to be used if no other SubTitleType value is applicable.
A Status of a Release in a supply chain.

: DeliveredToReleaseDistributor, InDeliveryToReleaseDistributor, InPreparationForDeliveryToReleaseDistributor, OrderPlacedForReleaseDistributor, ProcessingErrorAtReleaseCreator, ProcessingErrorAtReleaseDistributor, ReleaseMadeAvailableToConsumers, ReleaseNotAvailable, ReleaseReceivedByReleaseDistributor, ReleaseStagedForPublication, SuccessfullyIngestedByReleaseDistributor, UserDefined
A SupplyChainStatus indicating that a Release has been delivered to the ReleaseDistributor.
A SupplyChainStatus indicating that a Release is currently being delivered to the ReleaseDistributor.
A SupplyChainStatus indicating that a Release is currently being prepared to be delivered to the ReleaseDistributor.
A SupplyChainStatus indicating that an order for delivery has been placed with the ReleaseCreator.
A SupplyChainStatus indicating that the ReleaseCreator has encountered a processing Error with respect to the Release.
A SupplyChainStatus indicating that the ReleaseDistributor has encountered a processing Error with respect to the Release.
A SupplyChainStatus indicating that a Release has been made available to Consumers.
A SupplyChainStatus indicating that a Release is currently not available from the ReleaseCreator.
A SupplyChainStatus indicating that a Release has been received by the ReleaseDistributor.
A SupplyChainStatus indicating that a Release has been staged for publication by the ReleaseCreator.
A SupplyChainStatus indicating that a Release has been successfully ingested by the ReleaseDistributor.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.
A Type of Tax according to its scope.
: CombinedTax, FederalTax, LocalTax, ProvincialTax, StateTax, UserDefined
A Tax which is a combination of several Taxes.
A Tax which applies at the federal level.
A Tax which applies at the provincial level.
A Tax which applies at the state level.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.
A Tax which is a combination of several Taxes.
A Tax which is applicable to an Amount paid for a Product by an end Customer.
A Tax which has to be paid for Services.
A Tax which is applicable to an Amount at the source of the transaction.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.
A StandardIdentifier according to ISO 3166-1 Alpha 2 or ISO 3166-2 standard (or WorldWide). This is the default value. Note: only selected ISO 3166-2 codes are included.
A StandardIdentifier according to CISAC's Territory Information System.
A Type of TerritoryCode which also includes deprecated codes.
A StandardIdentifier according to ISO 3166-3 standard. Note: these codes are four-letter codes.
A StandardIdentifier according to ISO 3166-1 Alpha 2 or ISO 3166-2 standard (or WorldWide). This is the default value. Note: only selected ISO 3166-2 codes are included.
A StandardIdentifier according to CISAC's Territory Information System.
: ASCII, EBU-TT, HTML, OOXML, PDF, PostScript, RTF, SRT, TTML, Unknown, UserDefined, VTT
American Standard Code for Information Interchange as defined in ISO 464.
The EBU-TT format for subtitling data exchange (based on TTML), as defined by the European Broadcasting Union (aka EBU 3264).
HyperText Markup Language as defined by W3C.
Office Open XML for the representation of texts as defined in ISO/IEC 29500 (also known as Microsoft Word XML format).
Portable Document Format as defined by Adobe.
Rich Text Format as defined by Microsoft.
The SRT format as developed by SubRip.
Timed Text Markup Language, a coding format used for Captions, as defined by W3C.
A Type of an Entity used when a sender of a DdexMessage wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is unknown.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.
The Web Video Text Tracks format used for Captions, as defined by W3C.
: Caption, EBook, LinerNotes, LyricText, NonInteractiveBooklet, TextDocument, Unknown, UserDefined
A Resource that contains the text to be shown as subtitles, including closed or open captioning, as well as timing information
A digital equivalent of a conventionally printed book.
A Text included with a SoundCarrier, in the physical world typically in its sleeve or packaging. Example: a mix of factual, anecdotal and discographic material.
A Text consisting of the words of a MusicalWork.
A Text of a small book usually in reference to the packaging relating to a physical Creation which does not use technology that provides User interaction.
A written Text intended to communicate or store collections of data.
A Type of an Entity used when a sender of a DdexMessage wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is unknown.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.
A Extensible Hypertext Markup Language File (XHTML).
: ClosingTheme, MainTheme, OpeningTheme, SegmentTheme, TitleTheme, UserDefined
A Theme used in the final moments of the containing Resource, Collection or Release.
A Theme used throughout the containing Resource, Collection or Release.
A Theme used in the introduction of the containing Resource, Collection or Release.
A Theme used during a part of the containing Resource, Collection or Release.
A Theme used during the display of title of the containing Resource, Collection or Release.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.
A CISAC four-digit TIS code representing a Territory.
Taiwan, Province of China (Source: TIS Standard).
Congo, The Democratic Republic of The (Source: TIS Standard).
Holy See (Vatican City State) (Source: TIS Standard).
Iran, Islamic Republic of (Source: TIS Standard).
Korea, Democratic People's Republic of (Source: TIS Standard).
Lao People's Democratic Republic (Source: TIS Standard).
Micronesia, Federated States of (Source: TIS Standard).
Saint Kitts And Nevis (Source: TIS Standard).
Saint Vincent And The Grenadines (Source: TIS Standard).
Sao Tome And Principe (Source: TIS Standard).
Swaziland (Source: TIS Standard). Swaziland has recently changed its name to Eswatini. DDEX will update the value as soon as it becomes aware of a change in the TIS codes as governed by CISAC.
Macedonia, The Former Yugoslav Republic of (Source: TIS Standard).
Tanzania, United Republic of (Source: TIS Standard).
Commonwealth of Independent States (Source: TIS Standard).

A Type of Title which defines its origin, form or the function it fulfils in relation to a Creation. Note: A Title may fulfil more than one role. Example: 'Help' may be both the OriginalTitle and the DisplayTitle for the well-known Beatles song.

: AbbreviatedDisplayTitle, AlternativeTitle, DisplayTitle, FirstLineOfText, FormalTitle, GroupingTitle, IncorrectTitle, MisspelledTitle, OriginalTitle, SearchTitle, SortingTitle, TitleAsPart, TitleWithoutPunctuation, TranslatedTitle, Unknown, UserDefined
A shortened version of the DisplayTitle which may be used for devices that have limited display capability.

An alternative to a primary Title, e.g. a ReferenceTitle or a DisplayTitle. Example: a song may become well known or 'also known as (a.k.a.)' by its first line or a line from its chorus: 'Don't Stop Me Now' performed by Queen may have an AlternativeTitle 'Having A Good Time' or, 'I will always love you' performed by Whitney Houston may have an AlternativeTitle of 'Theme from Bodyguard'.
A Title expressed by the RightsController as to how a Title should be displayed for presentation to the Consumer.
A Title which consists of the first line of the text of which it is a Title.

A Title structured according to a naming convention. In many cases, a FormalTitle will be communicated together with a GroupingTitle. Example: This is often used for classical works. The 1st movement of Vivaldi's Spring concerto may have a FormalTitle of 'Concerto No. 1 in E major, Op. 8, RV 269, 'Spring' (La primavera), 1. Allegro (in E major)'.

A Title given to a grouping of Creations. This is often used for classical works to indicate the parent work to the one being described. In many cases, a GroupingTitle will be communicated together with a FormalTitle. Example: When describing the 1st movement of Vivaldi's Spring concerto, a suitable GroupingTitle would be its FormalTitle without the last part. 'Concerto No. 1 in E major, Op. 8, RV 269, 'Spring' (La primavera)'.
A Title by which a Creation is often incorrectly known.
A Title that contains common typographic errors.

A Title given to a Creation by its Creator(s), in its original Language. Note: A Creation may be given more than one OriginalTitle. Note: The OriginalTitle of a Creation X may be the DisplayTitle of a Creation that X is based on. Example: the OriginalTitle of the MusicalWork 'My Way' (whose lyrics were written by Paul Anka) is 'Comme d'habitude' (written and composed by Claude François).
A Title created to aid database searching (for example, where special characters, puns, or slang have been replaced by standardized elements).
A Title which has been arranged such that it can be used for alphabetic sorting.
A Title of a Creation as Part of another Creation.
A Title from which all initial articles and punctuation have been removed.

A translation into a different Language of the value contained in an OriginalTitle Element. Note: this is not the same as the OriginalTitle of a translation of a Creation, though the two will often be represented by the same text string. Example: the TranslatedTitle of 'Le Nozze di Figaro' is 'The Marriage Of Figaro'.
A Type of an Entity used when a sender of a DdexMessage wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is unknown.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.
A Part of a Track that a service is recommended to use when preparing a preview.
A Part of a Track that a DJ can talk over without obscuring the vocals or lead melody.
A Part of a Track that a service is recommended to use when preparing a preview.
A Part of a Track that has been used for some particular purpose which is given in a Comment.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.

: AlignmentTones, AnalogToDigitalConverter, BitDepth, Cartridge, NumberOfChannels, ClockSource, MaterialCondition, ConversionReferenceLevel, Emphasis, MicPreamp, NoiseReduction, PhonoPreamp, ReferenceClock, ReferenceTones, SamplingRate, Side1Condition, Side2Condition, NumberOfSides, SmpteFrameRate, SourceMachine, Speed, Storage, Stylus, StylusSize, TapeBakedDate, TapeBakedEquipment, TapeBakedHours, TapeBakedTemperature, TapeCoolHours, Tonearm, TrackConfiguration, NumberOfTracks, TransferSoftware
Laboratory test tones used to align the analog tape machine used in the Transfer.
The Analog To Digital converter used in the Transfer.
The bit depth of the Transfer.
The phono cartridge used in the Transfer.
The number of channels used in the Transfer. 'Stereo' and 'Mono' are common terms.
The clock source used in the Transfer.
The condition of the source material used in the Transfer.
The reference level relative to 0 VU of the Analog to Digital Conversion. '-16 dBFS = 0 VU' is a common example
The state of pre-emphasis of the digital source used in the Transfer ('On' of 'Off').
The Microphone preamplifier used in the Transfer.
The type of noise reduction used in the Transfer (can also be 'none').
The phono preamplifier used in the Transfer.
The reference clock used in the Transfer.
The printed test tones used to align the analog tape machine used in the Transfer.
The sampling rate of the Transfer.
The condition of Side 1 (Face 1) the source material used in the Transfer.
The condition of Side 2 (Face 2) the source material used in the Transfer.
The number of Sides of the source material used in the Transfer.
The SMPTE FrameRate of the Transfer.
The source machine used in the Transfer.
The speed of the source machine used in the Transfer. 30 ips or 33 rpm are common terms.
The storage of the material used in the Transfer. 'Tails Out' and 'Heads Out' are common terms.
The stylus used in the Transfer.
The stylus size used in the Transfer.
The date the tape was baked in preparation for Transfer.
The equipment used to 'bake' the reel of tape in preparation for Transfer.
The time the reel of tape was 'baked' in preparation for Transfer.
The temperature at which the reel of tape was 'baked' in preparation for Transfer.
The time the reel of tape was cooled after 'baking' in preparation for Transfer.
The tonearm used in the Transfer.
The track configuration used in the Transfer. 'Half Track', 'Multitrack' and 'Quarter Track' are common terms
The number of tracks in the Transfer.
The transfer Software used in the Transfer.
A transfer of analog to analog audio.
A transfer of analog to digital audio.
A copy of a digital audio.
A transfer of digital to analog audio.
A transfer of digital to digital audio.
A UnitOfMeasure for a condition value.
A Type of a nature of a Service, or a Release, as used by a Consumer.

: AsPerContract, Broadcast, Cable, ConditionalDownload, ContentInfluencedStream, Display, Download, DubForAdvertisement, DubForLivePerformance, DubForMovies, DubForMusicOnHold, DubForPublicPerformance, DubForRadio, DubForTV, ExtractForInternet, KioskDownload, Narrowcast, NonInteractiveStream, OnDemandStream, PerformAsMusicOnHold, PerformInLivePerformance, PerformInPublic, PermanentDownload, Playback, PlayInPublic, Podcast, Print, PrivateCopy, PurchaseAsPhysicalProduct, Rent, Simulcast, Stream, TetheredDownload, TimeInfluencedStream, Unknown, UseAsAlertTone, UseAsDevice, UseAsKaraoke, UseAsRingbackTone, UseAsRingbackTune, UseAsRingtone, UseAsRingtune, UseAsScreensaver, UseAsVoiceMail, UseAsWallpaper, UseForIdentification, UseInMobilePhoneMessaging, UseInPhoneListening, UserDefined, UserMakeAvailableLabelProvided, UserMakeAvailableUserProvided, Webcast
A Type of an Entity used when a MessageSender wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is defined by the contractual relationship between MessageSender and MessageRecipient.
To Deliver a Resource using radio waves on the radio frequency portion of the electromagnetic spectrum. This allowed value should only be used in the context of the MLC standard.
Deprecation: This allowed value has been deprecated in 2017-11. DDEX advises that this value will be removed at a future date and therefore recommends against using it.
To transmit a Release via a cable network as used by, e.g., Cable TV providers. This allowed value should only be used in the context of the MLC standard.
To Download under a condition (e.g. tethered to a Service or device).

To Stream where the only interactivity provided allows the Consumer to start, stop, pause, fast forward and rewind the Stream, and where there is limited flexibility to influence the content of the Stream.
To display a Resource on a device where it will disappear when the device is switched off.
Deprecation: This allowed value has been deprecated in 2017-11. DDEX advises that this value will be removed at a future date and therefore recommends against using it.
To transfer a Release from a service's Computer to a consumer's Computer for later consumption (e.g. ConditionalDownload, PermanentDownload, TetheredDownload, KioskDownload).
Deprecation: This allowed value has been deprecated in 2017-11. DDEX advises that this value will be removed at a future date and therefore recommends against using it.
To reproduce an AudioResource in the creation of the soundtrack of an audio or audio-visual Advertisement. Note: this use does not include the public performance of the included Resource.
To reproduce a Resource to enable a live Performance event. Note: this includes dramatic performances, dance shows and fashion exhibitions.
To reproduce an AudioResource in the creation of a soundtrack of an audio-visual Work. Note: this use does not include the public performance of the included Resource.
To reproduce an AudioResource in the creation of a music on hold system. Note: this use does not include the public performance of the included Resource.
To reproduce an AudioResource to enable a public Performance. Note: this use does not include the public performance of the included Resource.
To reproduce an AudioResource to enable any form of radio transmission. Note: this use does not include the public performance of the included Resource.
To reproduce an AudioResource to enable any form of television transmission. Note: this use does not include the public performance of the included Resource.

To reproduce and make available an excerpt from a Resource in an on demand internet streaming service. This use applies for example to excerpts/previews of sound recordings that consumers can listen to on-demand on sites such as Amazon or iTunes before buying the previewed product.
To Download directly from a Kiosk to a consumer device. This allowed value should only be used in the context of the MLC standard.
To Deliver a Resource to a specific list of recipients, by terrestrial or satellite transmission. This allowed value should only be used in the context of the MLC standard.
Deprecation: This allowed value has been deprecated in 2017-11. DDEX advises that this value will be removed at a future date and therefore recommends against using it.

To Stream a Release as part of a scheduled program that has been a-priori arranged. Consumers cannot directly influence the content or order of a NonInteractiveStream. NonInteractiveStreams are often referred to as web casts or pre-programmed Streams.
To Stream a Release with full interactivity.
To Perform a Resource in a music on hold service.
To Perform a Resource as part of a live Performance event. Note: this includes dramatic performances, dance shows and fashion exhibitions.
To Perform publicly. This allowed value should only be used in the context of the MLC standard.
Deprecation: This allowed value has been deprecated in 2017-11. DDEX advises that this value will be removed at a future date and therefore recommends against using it.
To Download for permanent storage and subsequent consumption by the Consumer.
To play a Resource in a Release as an analogue signal for listening and/or viewing by an individual or small group.
To play a Resource in a Release publicly. This UseType is typically used when reporting such usages to rights holders.
To Deliver a series of Resources as a download via web syndication.
To Copy a Resource on paper or an another permanent Medium where it can be seen.
Deprecation: This allowed value has been deprecated in 2017-11. DDEX advises that this value will be removed at a future date and therefore recommends against using it.
To Copy a Resource for private use. This UseType is typically used when reporting revenues related to private copying levies.
To allow access to a Release for a limited Period of Time.
To Stream simultaneously over two or more different media systems or channels. This allowed value should only be used in the context of the MLC standard.
Deprecation: This allowed value has been deprecated in 2017-11. DDEX advises that this value will be removed at a future date and therefore recommends against using it.
To stream a Resource (e.g. NonInteractiveStream, OnDemandStream, TimeInfluencedStream, ContentInfluencedStream, Simulcast).
To Download to a tethered download host (a device which must be connected to a DSP's service through a broadband connection whenever a downloaded Resource is played).
To Stream where the only interactivity provided allows the Consumer to start, stop, pause, fast forward and rewind the Stream.
A Type of an Entity used when a sender of a DdexMessage wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is unknown.
To use a Resource in a Release as an alert primarily on a MobileTelephone for an event other than an incoming phone call. Examples: an incoming text message or a new voice mail.
To Use a Resource in a Release that has been provided to a Consumer as part of a hardware purchase.
The use of a Release for a form of entertainment in which an amateur singer or singers sing along with recorded music on microphone.
To Use a Resource in a Release as the audible ringing that is heard primarily on a MobileTelephone by the calling party after dialing and prior to the call being answered at the receiving end.
To Use a Resource in a Release as ringbacktune.
To Use a Resource in a Release as an alert for an incoming phone call primarily on a MobileTelephone.
To Use a Resource in a Release as ringtune.
Deprecation: This allowed value has been deprecated in 2017-11. DDEX advises that this value will be removed at a future date and therefore recommends against using it.
To use a Resource in a Release as a screen saver for an idling device.
To Use a Resource as a voice greeting that contains an audio master clip in the background. Such a greeting can be used for outgoing and/or incoming voicemails.

To use a Resource in a Release to aid identification processes (e.g. to support rights management operations where a record company provides sound recordings to a service provider for fingerprinting or watermarking). For the avoidance of doubt: this UseType does not include making the Release available to Consumers.
To reproduce and perform a Resource in a phone messaging system.
To reproduce and perform a Resource in a service for phone based listening.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.

A UseType in which Consumers use a Release as part of their own Creation (e.g. a web site) only when the Release is provided by the ReleaseCreator to the service provider (e.g. the web site hosting company) and where the ReleaseCreator has stipulated to the service provider the ways in which the Release may be used by Consumers and these stipulations are conveyed to Consumers.

A UseType in which Consumers use a Release as part of their own Creation (e.g. a web site) when the Release is not provided by the ReleaseCreator to the service provider (e.g. the web site hosting company) but by the Consumer or by other Consumers making the Release available through the service provider.
To Deliver a Resource over the Internet using streaming technology. This allowed value should only be used in the context of the MLC standard.
Deprecation: This allowed value has been deprecated in 2017-11. DDEX advises that this value will be removed at a future date and therefore recommends against using it.
A Type of a nature of a Service, or a Release, as used by a Consumer, as used in the MWNL messages.
To Stream a Release with full interactivity.
To Download for permanent storage and subsequent consumption by the Consumer.
To Use a Resource in a Release as an alert for an incoming phone call primarily on a MobileTelephone.
A Type of physical interface by which a Consumer uses a Service or Release.
: AsPerContract, ConnectedDevice, GameConsole, Jukebox, KaraokeMachine, Kiosk, LocalStorageJukebox, PersonalComputer, PhysicalMediaWriter, PortableDevice, RemoteStorageJukebox, Unknown, UserDefined
A Type of an Entity used when a MessageSender wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is defined by the contractual relationship between MessageSender and MessageRecipient.
A device for interacting with Releases that is directly connected to the Internet. This includes set-top boxes.
An interactive entertainment Computer or electronic device with the primary function to manipulate the video display signal of a display device (a television, monitor, etc.) to display a Game.
A device for playing back audio and/or audio-visual Resources in a defined public location on demand by an individual Consumer usually following payment.
A device in a fixed physical location for vending Resources chosen by an individual Consumer usually upon payment onto a physical Carrier.
A Jukebox where the Releases are stored locally.

A small Computer based on a microprocessor. In addition to the microprocessor, a PersonalComputer has a keyboard for entering data, a monitor for displaying information, speakers for producing sound and a storage device for saving data. A PersonalComputer may be a desktop or laptop, and it may run a variety of OperatingSystems.
A device that can be used to transfer Resources to physical media such as CD-ROMs, DVDs or flash memory.
A small, portable device with many of the features of a laptop PersonalComputer, which is also or primarily designed for storing, organizing and playing Resources.
A Jukebox where the Releases are stored remotely and are accessed during play-back.
A Type of an Entity used when a sender of a DdexMessage wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is unknown.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.

: AcapellaVersion, AlbumVersion, AlternativeVersion, CleanVersion, DemoVersion, EditedVersion, InstrumentalVersion, KaraokeVersion, LiveVersion, MixVersion, MonoVersion, RadioVersion, RemixVersion, SessionVersion, SingleVersion, StereoVersion, UserDefined
A Version with only vocal music.
A Version produced for an Album.
A Version that does not contain any offending elements.
A Version produced for demonstration purposes.
A Version that has been edited (no details specified).
A Version with only instrumental music.
A Version recorded at a live performance.
A Version that is a mix.
A Version produced for radio stations.
A Version that is a remix.
A Version that is the result of a Session.
A Version produced for a Single.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.
: AVC, H.261, H.263, MPEG-1, MPEG-2, MPEG-4, QuickTime, RealVideo, Shockwave, Unknown, UserDefined, WMV
Advanced Video Coding as specified in ISO/IEC 14496-10.
A VideoCodec as specified in ITU-T H.261.
A VideoCodec as specified in ITU-T H.263.
A VideoCodec defined by the Moving Pictures Expert Group and specified in ISO/IEC 11172-2.
A VideoCodec defined by the Moving Pictures Expert Group and specified in ISO/IEC 13818-2.
A VideoCodec defined by the Moving Pictures Expert Group and specified in ISO/IEC 14469-2.
QuickTime as developed by Apple Inc.
Real Video as developed by RealNetworks Inc.
Shockwave as developed by Macromedia Inc.
A Type of an Entity used when a sender of a DdexMessage wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is unknown.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.
Windows Media Video as developed by Microsoft Corp.
A Type of resolution (or definition) in which a Video is provided.
A VideoDefinitionType of a Video that is provided in a resolution exceeding 704 x 480 pixels.
A VideoDefinitionType of a Video that is provided in a resolution not exceeding 704 x 480 pixels.
values from avs:VideoType_DSRF, avs:AdditionalVideoType. Please refer to the data dictionary for a full list
A Video which promotes a product, service, idea, person or company, including promotional material for consumer products, services shown in theaters, infomercials or on digital signage.
Content, such as pornography or violence, that is not generally thought to be appropriate for viewing by children.
A Magazine that provides information about general topics for a broad audience.
An audio-visual Recording using a rapid display of a sequence of images of 2-D or 3-D artwork or model positions in order to create an illusion of movement.
A Video recording of a ballet Performance.
An audio-visual Recording documenting events happening behind the scenes.
An audio-visual Recording in black and white.
A FeatureFilm or TvFilm for an audience of children.
An audio-visual Recording which has been colorized.
A Video of a recurring piece or feature in a radio or TV program.
A Video recording of a live Performance, usually of music, before an audience.
An audio-visual Recording made for use within a corporate entity. Examples include company-internal training videos.
An audio-visual Recording that presents the list of Contributors to an audio-visual production.
An audio-visual Recording that presents a social, political, scientific or historical subject. Documentaries include current affairs programmes, TV magazines, biographies and 'making of' programs.
An audio-visual Recording of traditional training, coursework, classroom or distance learning. Such Videos are primarily intended to educate rather than entertain.
A Part of a Series made available at a specific point in time. It may be that a Season or Series is not yet complete when an Episode is made available. Episodes include 'pilots'.
An audio-visual Recording made for initial distribution in cinemas, where it would be the 'main attraction' of the screening, or prime-time television.
A Video created to advertise a Product or Service in an informative way.
An audio-visual Recording of an interview.
A Video for Karaoke applications, typically for singing along to.
An audio-visual Recording capturing an Event such as a sporting event, theatrical performances, etc.
Deprecation: This allowed value has been deprecated in 2017-11. DDEX advises that this value will be removed at a future date and therefore recommends against using it.
A Video of an extended duration typically containing multiple tracks embodying at least one MusicalWork. Example: a concert video. LongFormMusicalWorkVideos are typically identified by an ISRC.
A Video of an extended duration not embodying a MusicalWork.
An audio-visual Recording (often a slide show), with captions showing the lyrics.
An audio-visual Recording of a regular television or radio programme comprising a variety of topical items.
An aid to navigate through a Video which may be organized, e.g., into chapters. Menus are typically used on a DVD-Video.
An extract from a Video, embodying a MusicalWork.
A Video to read along to, and interact with, stories and songs, embodying a MusicalWork.
A Video created for specifically to promote another Video, embodying a MusicalWork.
An audio-visual Recording, usually regularly scheduled, which reports current events.
An extract from a Video, not specifically embodying a MusicalWork.
A Video to read along to, and interact with, stories and songs, not embodying a MusicalWork.
A Video created for specifically to promote another Video, not embodying a MusicalWork.
A VideoChapter not embodying a MusicalWork.
An audio-visual Recording that is not part of a Series or Season.
A Video recording of Performance of an opera.

An audio-visual Recording of a Performance such as recitation, magic, circus, stand-up comedy, burlesque, vaudeville or other variety stage act. This does not include concerts, dance, music, opera, theatrical productions.
A Video to read along to, and interact with, stories and songs.
A TvShowVideo of supposedly unscripted real-life contexts.

A Set of Episodes. Typically, a Season contains all Episodes to be made available in a pre-determined time frame, which often is within a twelve-month period. It may be that a Series is not yet complete when a Season is made available.
An audio-visual Recording of a work divided into two or more episodes which generally have the same title and a dramatic continuity between episodes.
A Set of Resources (Episodes) designed to be made available sequentially.
A fictional audio-visual Recording with an original length less than that of a FeatureFilm. This does not include short animated films.
A Video recording of a short satirical theatrical Performance.
A Video recording of a work, comprising of episodes, involving the same main performers, with a unity of place and generally broadcasted on a daily basis.
An audio-visual Recording capturing an Event not related to sport or performances or concerts, such as a political convention or a talk show.
An audio-visual Recording of a sporting Event.
A Video recording of Performance of a theatrical work.
A Video not specifically embodying a MusicalWork specifically created to promote another Video.
A fictional audio-visual Recording made specifically for initial broadcasting on television networks.
An audio-visual Recording of a regular television or radio programme.
A Video recording of a TV show including reality programmes, magazines, variety shows, game shows. TvShowVideo should be used when no other value of VideoType is appropriate.
A Type of an Entity used when a sender of a DdexMessage wishes to indicate that the value within the allowed value set is unknown.
A section of a Video defined by a start and end point. Typical VideoChapters are MusicalWorkVideoChapter or NonMusicalWorkVideoChapter.
An audio-visual Recording of an account or statement describing in detail an event, situation, or the like, usually as the result of observation, inquiry, investigation.
An unedited audio-visual Recording that was recorded as part of a Session to produce, for instance, a ShortFormMusicalWorkVideo, but that has not been incorporated into the final version.

A Video whose audio content corresponds exactly or approximately to that of an audio-only Single which embodies at least one MusicalWork. ShortFormMusicalWorkVideos are typically identified by an ISRC.
A Video of a short ended duration not specifically embodying a MusicalWork.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.
A Type of Video, as used in the DSRF Messages.

A Type of MusicalCreation according to how it is experienced in an audio-visual Creation.
Music which is dubbed in for effect. It is not heard by the actors or performers in an audio-visual Creation.
A Type of an Entity which is defined by a sender of a DdexMessage in a manner acceptable to its recipient.

A Type of a MusicalCreation that is visibly experienced by the characters in the containing Resource, Collection or Release (e.g. a character sings a song or actively listens to a song played on the radio).
A Type of a MusicalCreation according to the occurrence of vocals.
A Type of a MusicalCreation that contains only (musical) instruments.
